findings: Political Priorities and Strategies Viet Nam has demonstrated its strong determination to orient the development of AI through the promulgation of the National Strategy on Research, Development, and Application of Artificial Intelligence by 2030 under Decision No.

This Strategy sets out the strategic objective of positioning Viet Nam among the top four ASEAN countries and the world’s top 50 in AI research, development, and application by 2030, reflecting a long-term vision and ambition to harness AI as a key driver of economic growth and innovation.

In February 2024, the Ministry of Science and Technology reported the results of the three-year implementation of the National AI Strategy, based on consolidated assessments from ministries, sectors, and localities during the implementation process.

The report highlighted several constraints and their causes, while outlining directions and key tasks for the coming period, including the continued review and improvement of institutions and policies on AI.

Recently, the Politburo has promulgated several strategic resolutions on science and technology, law-making and enforcement, and private sector development, which directly introduce a number of new and groundbreaking policies to foster AI development in Viet Nam.

findings: National Strategy and Policies on AI Development Viet Nam has recognized early on the importance of AI and has promulgated the National Strategy on Research, Development, and Application of AI by 2030.

In addition, the Strategy mandates the creation of 50 open shared datasets for AI research and development; the establishment of a legal framework for AI; the development of an AI ecosystem (including networks of startups and research communities); and the promotion of international cooperation in A

Alongside the National AI Strategy, the Government is also implementing related programmes such as the National Digital Transformation Programme and the National Strategy on the Fourth Industrial Revolution, in which AI is regarded as a foundational technology.
These policies demonstrate that Viet Nam is pursuing an approach that encompasses infrastructure, data, human resources, legal frameworks, and the startup ecosystem.

Ethical considerations on the impacts of AI require an approach that integrates and analyses the technological, sociocultural, anthropological, psychological, and even political dimensions of AI adoption.
Research Output The number of AI publications from Viet Nam has been growing rapidly, reflecting the dynamism of the research community.
However, in terms of overall output, per capita rate, and especially quality and average impact, Viet Nam still needs to make significant efforts to catch up with advanced countries.
Continued strategic investment, with a focus on quality and human resource development, is key to ensuring the sustainable growth of the AI sector in Viet Nam.
strengths: This demonstrates a strong commitment to prioritizing resources and institutional frameworks for technological development.

The Readiness Assessment Methodology (RAM) is a diagnostic tool intended to assist Member States in upholding their commitment to the Recommendation by helping them understand how prepared they are to implement AI ethically and responsibly for all their citizens.

By highlighting any institutional, regulatory, or data gaps and obstacles, it enables UNESCO to tailor support for governments to fill those gaps to ensure an ethical AI ecosystem aligned with the Recommendation.
Its recommendations aim to support the Government in strengthening the National AI Strategy, ensuring that innovation is pursued in alignment with ethics, human rights, and sustainable development.
strengths: That is why UNESCO drafted the Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, which was adopted in 2021 by 193 countries to make sure AI delivers fair, sustainable, and inclusive outcomes.
This assessment provides a comprehensive overview of Viet Nam’s capacities, opportunities, and challenges in advancing responsible AI.

The report highlights the strong commitment of the Government of Viet Nam to promoting AI and digital transformation as a key driver of economic progress, in support of the country’s ambition to become a high-income, developed nation by 2045.

In response to these challenges, 193 UNESCO Member States adopted the Recommendation on the Ethics of AI in 2021, establishing the first global standard to help countries harness the benefits of AI while mitigating its associated risks.
Viet Nam launched its RAM in August 2024 under the leadership and guidance of the Ministry of Science and Technology (MST).

While a comprehensive AI legal framework is still under development, the country already has strong legislation in related areas such as data protection, privacy, cybersecurity, open data, and public accountability, providing a solid foundation for responsible AI development.

gaps: It is not acceptable that around a third of the world’s population still lacks adequate internet access.

The Recommendation also sets out concrete policy actions that governments can draw on to steer technological developments in a responsible direction, premised on the belief that light-touch regulation, which has until now remained the norm, is insufficient.
These include the absence of dedicated AI laws and binding mechanisms to operationalize responsible AI principles, as well as the lack of a unified coordinating body for AI governance.

In the context of digital transformation and improving the science and technology framework, we need to continue promoting international cooperation, building capacity, and developing a strong AI ecosystem to seize opportunities and effectively manage the challenges of the digital era.
However, to realize this vision, we need broader and deeper international cooperation and learn from global best practices.
However, it also raises serious ethical concerns.
The National AI Strategy (2021) sets out objectives for digital infrastructure, economic growth, and public sector innovation but does not include ethical provisions.
However, these principles are advisory in nature and not legally binding.
While this is a positive development, these principles have yet to be embedded across the legal and policy landscape.
As AI systems grow more complex and influential, the need for a dedicated and enforceable ethical AI framework becomes increasingly urgent.

achievements.achievement: DATA PROTECTION AND PRIVACY LAWS Viet Nam has established a comprehensive legal framework for the protection of personal data and privacy.

Privacy rights are recognized and enshrined in the 2013 Constitution, the 2015 Civil Code, and various specialized laws such as the 2015 Law on Cyber Information Security, the 2018 Law on Cybersecurity, the Law on Medical Examination and Treatment, the Law on Children, the Law on Education, the Law on Insurance Business, and the Law on Credit Institutions, among others.

Although Viet Nam has not officially adopted the International Open Data Charter, it has established a basic legal framework for national data sharing through the 2024 Law on Data (effective from 1 July 2025).

These legal instruments have established a relatively systematic legal framework to determine the conditions giving rise to liability, the entities responsible for compensation, the extent of such compensation, and so forth.

ONLINE SAFETY AND INTEGRITY OF SPEECH As mentioned under section 2.2 of this report, Viet Nam has established a comprehensive legal framework for cybersecurity, which covers both online safety and integrity of speech.

From a legal perspective, the general principle of gender equality has been clearly and consistently recognized in the 2013 Constitution and the 2006 Law on Gender Equality, and it has also been mainstreamed into laws related to the fields of science and technology, information and communications, and electronic transactions, such as the 2008 Law on High Technology, the 2013 Law on Science and Technology, the 2023 Law on Electronic Transactions, and the 2023 Law on Telecommunications.
From a strategic and policy perspective, Viet Nam has issued and implemented strategies and policies on gender equality, digital transformation, and the digital economy.

The 2006 Law on Gender Equality and the National Gender Equality Strategy for the 2021–2030 period have established a general legal and policy framework for gender equality across all sectors, including science and technology.

In addition, Viet Nam has adopted and implemented the 2021–2025 National Target Programmes, including the National Target Programme on Sustainable Poverty Reduction and the National Target Programme on New Rural Development.

National Strategy and Policies on AI Development Viet Nam has recognized early on the importance of AI and has promulgated the National Strategy on Research, Development, and Application of AI by 2030.

Particularly, the Viet Nam Academy of Science and Technology (VAST) has founded the Advanced Centre for Artificial Intelligence with the aim of promoting interdisciplinary research and training highly skilled AI professionals.
Within the corporate sector, several AI research and development organizations in Viet Nam have reached regional scale and recognition.

The most prominent example is VinAI Research (under Vingroup), which was founded in 2019 and rapidly entered the Top 20 leading AI research companies worldwide in 2022 (ranked 20th) – the only representative from Southeast Asia on the list.73 VinAI focuses on machine learning, computer vision, and NLP, and has published extensively at the world’s premier AI conferences, thereby making a significant contribution to elevating Viet Nam’s global standing in AI research.

In addition, Viet Nam’s AI startup ecosystem has been vibrant, with notable players such as Zalo AI (VNG) – recognized for its speech recognition systems and research presented at PRICAI 2021 – as well as VAIS (a speech recognition startup), AIOZ, and Earable AI.

Master’s and doctoral programmes in AI have also begun to be implemented at several key institutes and universities.

recommendations.title: Principles and Rights of Data Subjects (Article 4)
recommendations.text: Principles and Rights of Data Subjects (Article 4) Building on the approach of Decree 13/2023/ND-CP, the Law on Personal Data Protection affirms the principle of granting data subjects’ control over their own data, i.e., the persons to whom the personal information pertains. These rights are specified in Article 4 of the Law on Personal Data Protection and include the right to be informed about how their data is collected, processed, and used; the right to consent or refuse, and to withdraw consent for the processing of personal data; the right to access, correct, or request correction of personal data; and the right to request the provision, deletion, or restriction of personal data processing.

recommendations.title: Sensitive Data Protection (Article 26,31,38)
recommendations.text: Sensitive Data Protection (Article 26,31,38) The Law on Personal Data Protection also distinguishes between basic personal data and sensitive personal data, emphasizing that sensitive personal data relates to an individual’s privacy and, if infringed, would directly affect the rights and legitimate interests of agencies, organizations, or individuals, as listed in the government-issued catalogue. Sensitive data protection is subject to stricter safeguards. It requires explicit consent and additional protective measures due to its greater potential impact if misused.

recommendations.title: Consent Mechanism (Article 9 and Article 16 and 19)
recommendations.text: Consent Mechanism (Article 9 and Article 16 and 19) Article 9 of the Law on Personal Data Protection requires organizations collecting personal data to obtain permission from the data subject to process their personal data. The law further stipulates that the consent of the data subject is only valid if it is given voluntarily and with full knowledge of (i) the type of personal data to be processed and the purpose of such processing, (ii) the data controller or the data controller and processor, and (iii) the rights and obligations of the data subject. At the same time, the data subject’s consent must be expressed clearly and explicitly, in a tangible form that can be printed or recorded in writing, including in electronic or verifiable formats. Article 16 limits disclosure to specific, lawful purposes, requiring accuracy, controlled access, and safeguards against unauthorized use. Article 19 permits processing without consent only in defined urgent, legal, or public interest cases, subject to oversight and risk management.

recommendations.title: Responsibilities of Data Controllers and Processors (Article 37)
recommendations.text: Responsibilities of Data Controllers and Processors (Article 37) The Law on Personal Data Protection clearly stipulates the obligations and responsibilities of the data controller and the data processor. It emphasizes that the data controller, in the capacity of an agency, organization, or individual, who 2 International Telecommunication Union, Global Cybersecurity Index, 2024, Retrieved from https://www.itu.int/epublications/publication/global- cybersecurity-index-2024 24 Viet Nam - Artificial Intelligence Readiness Assessment Report determines the purposes and means of processing personal data, must ensure the rights of the data subjects, be liable to the data subjects for any damages caused by the personal data processing, and prevent unauthorized personal data collection from its systems, devices, and services (Clause 1, Article 37). For agencies, organizations, or individuals performing personal data processing at the request of the data controller or the data controller and processor under a contract, Clause 2, Article 37 of the Law on Personal Data Protection stipulates that the data processor may only receive personal data after entering into an agreement or contract on personal data processing with the data controller or the data controller and processor, and must process personal data strictly in accordance with the terms of the signed agreement or contract.

recommendations.title: Impact Assessments (Article 24)
recommendations.text: Impact Assessments (Article 24) The Law on Personal Data Protection also prescribes procedures for conducting impact assessments on personal data processing as well as on the transfer of personal data abroad, assigning the Government the responsibility to provide detailed regulations on the required documentation, conditions, and procedural steps for carrying out these impact assessments.

recommendations.title: Enforcement Mechanism (Article 33, 35,36, 4 and 8)
recommendations.text: Enforcement Mechanism (Article 33, 35,36, 4 and 8) Article 33 of the Law on Personal Data Protection defines the personal data protection force, which includes the specialized personal data protection agency under the Ministry of Public Security; internal personal data protection units and personnel within agencies and organizations; organizations and individuals providing personal data protection services; and organizations and individuals mobilized to participate in personal data protection. Among these, the Ministry of Public Security is designated as the focal agency responsible to the Government for state management of personal data protection. In addition, article 4(1)(đ) grants data subjects the right to seek compensation for damages. Article 8 provides enforcement mechanisms, including administrative fines, criminal liability, and mandatory compensation.

recommendations.title: Public vs. Private Sector Standards
recommendations.text: Public vs. Private Sector Standards The PDPL applies the same standards to all entities but allows specific exemptions for public authorities. For example, Article 19(1)(c) permits processing without consent to serve state agency operations, while Articles 19(1)(a)–(b) grant broader grounds for processing in matters of national security, public order, and emergencies.

recommendations.title: AI Skill Penetration
recommendations.text: AI Skill Penetration AI Skill Penetration in IT Workforce Viet Nam ranks within the top 10% of the Asia-Pacific region and 54th globally in technology skills.103 Based on survey data regarding the proportion of IT engineer positions within the IT workforce, the number of employees working as AI engineers is approximately 23,425 (according to data published by the Ministry of Information and Communications in 2024, the total IT workforce is 1,232,869, and the Vietnamworks report (2025) indicates that 1.9% of the IT workforce hold AI engineer positions). Additionally, the professional qualifications of IT personnel are impressive, with 86% of Viet Nam’s IT workforce holding a university or college degree, of which around 7.5% hold a master’s degree.104 However, the number of highly specialized AI professionals in Viet Nam remains scarce, with roughly 5,000 AI engineers, 7,000 AI specialists, and personnel in approximately 500 AI startups.105,106 Compared to current labour market demand, the number of professionals with AI expertise remains significantly insufficient.
